content: The service sector encompasses a wide range of economic activities that involve providing human value-added in various forms. These activities are intangible, cannot be stored, and must be consumed at the point of production. Rapid technological changes are expanding the possibilities for service delivery. Examples of services include retail trade, transportation, information, banking, education, healthcare, and more. Services are a significant sector of the U.S. economy. The service sector in the U.S. economy includes trade, transportation, information, banking, insurance, professional services, education, arts, health care, food services, construction, communication, and public administration. Services account for 83% of nonagricultural payroll jobs and 65% of GDP. Financial services are crucial for capital flow, delivery services ensure goods availability, and distribution services make goods accessible to consumers. Inefficiencies in these industries could have adverse effects on the economy. Delivery services are crucial for ensuring goods availability in the economy. U.S. trade in services plays a significant role in overall trade, accounting for 30% of total exports and 17% of total imports in 2010.
